As the first woman of color in Congress, Rep. Mink was pivotal in passing bills to expand childcare, and education bills including Head Start. She worked to protect the environment and fix our immigration system. https://t.co/TszDAKGP17

Crucially, she led the way to pass Title IX, which today protects students from sexual discrimination. After her death, Title IX was renamed the Patsy T. Mink Equal Opportunity in Education Act in her honor.

In the 1950s, she became involved in politics, working with Japanese-American veterans suffering discrimination despite honorable service in WWII. She ran for office and won. Then Hawaii became a state. She ran for Congress. She lost, ran again, and won. https://t.co/zPnViKsU6D
She would go on to fight throughout her life to end racial and gender discrimination, saying, ‚ÄúWe have to build things...to make sure that others do not have to suffer the same discrimination.‚Äù

Patsy dreamed of being a doctor. She attended a segregated college. Ten medical schools turned her down. She attended law school instead. She passed the bar. No firm would hire her. So, she opened her own, becoming the first Japanese-American woman to practice law in Hawaii.

Patsy Takemoto Mink was the first woman of color elected to the U.S. Congress, and a lifelong champion of civil rights and human dignity. Here‚Äôs her story as we celebrate #AAPIHeritageMonth https://t.co/qre1Xx76uE

She continued to work, becoming an important voice in the effort to expand voting rights to America's women.

Congress eventually passed a bill to give her a small, reduced pension of $20 per month. https://t.co/M0NN0ySpY0

Later in her life she lived in poverty. Her status as a Black woman made it nearly impossible to get the pension she had earned in the war. She faced other discrimination. A train conductor threw her from a train car, breaking her arm. She was scammed and robbed.

Meanwhile, she spoke, and organized. The abolitionist John Brown called her "General Tubman." When the Civil War began, she continued to fight for abolition, condemning Lincoln for his timidity. "God won't let master Lincoln beat the South till he does the right thing," she said.

As the war progressed, she became a nurse and scout, then put the "General Tubman" title to the test, becoming the first woman to lead an armed assault during the Civil War and leading a mass evacuation of over 750 slaves, many of whom joined the war effort.

They had to flee to Canada because pro-slavery politicians in the U.S. had passed the Fugitive Slave Act to allow slavehunters to come North and kidnap escaped Americans. ‚ÄúAfter that," said Tubman, "I wouldn‚Äôt trust Uncle Sam with my people no longer." https://t.co/OuEjq4Q1lu

Tubman was five feet tall but fierce as lightning. She carried a revolver, even once using it to threaten a man who gave into fear and wanted to turn back, endangering the whole group. Reportedly, she told him ‚Äúyou‚Äôll be free or die.‚Äù They made it to Canada together. https://t.co/lgvJu4ZWbB

She spoke of the experience of winning her own freedom: ‚ÄúWhen I found I had crossed that line, I looked at my hands to see if I was the same person. There was such a glory over everything; the sun came like gold through trees, and over the fields, and I felt like I was in Heaven‚Äù

Today, Tubman is famous for her work with the Underground Railroad. She once said, "I never ran my train off the track and I never lost a passenger.‚Äù

She undertook 13 missions in 11 years, rescuing around 70 enslaved Americans.

There was one of two things I had a right to ‚Äì liberty or death. If I could not have one, I would have the other."
